answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some resources you may find useful.
You can learn more about improving emergency communication from the 311 Disaster Response & Recovery Tool Kit. The page below describes best practices and case studies about using 311 to communicate in emergency situations.
http://icma.org/en/Page/100225/311CRM_and_Disaster_Response
This article is about an automated alert system from Portland, OR.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/7607/Automated_Alert_Network
Lancaster County, NE uses a system of PC based emergency alerts.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/1261/PCbased_Emergency_Alerts
This article discusses a partnership formed by the FCC, FEMA, and the wireless industry to provide free geographically-targeted messages alerting customers of local threats. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/newsroom/highlights/Article/101191/Mobile_and_Online_Resources_for_Emergencies
This emergency response policy from Minneapolis includes a three phase alert system.
http://www.ci.minneapolis.mn.us/mpdpolicy/7-900/7-900.asp
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Marianne Bond
text: Does anyone use a system for city employees in the event of an active shooter/hostage situation or even an alert system in the event of a natural disaster or serious weather event?  If so are there levels to the alerts or a reference card for employees?
title: Text/email alerts for employees at city hall
